a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: About seven lines, with revisions, toward the poem "To the Year 1889." The writing on the verso (not in Whitman's hand) makes reference to the title of this poem, as well as to Good-Bye My Fancy and a "Putnam 1902 Edition." "To the Year 1889" was first published on January 5, 1889, in the Critic. The poem was retitled "To the Pending Year" for its inclusion in Good-Bye My Fancy (1891).

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: [Have I no word for thee]
bibl.idno: Rare Book Division; NYPL Catalog ID (B-number): b12414503; MSS Unit ID: 1767
bibl.orgName: The Oscar Lion Papers, New York Public Library, New York, N.Y.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

The The writing on the verso (not in Whitman's hand) makes reference to the title of this poem, as well as to Good-Bye My Fancy and a "Putnam 1902 Edition." Archival notations are also stamped and handwritten on the verso.

lg.l: Have I no word for thee—someno brief, andor fierce

Have I fought out the battlewholly? Is there
no shot left yet in the chest ‸yet?
For all thy affectations, lisps, scorns, silliness,
Notr for myself—my worstown rebellion's selfwillth thee.self?
Down, down proud gorge, tho' choking thee!

His Crouch, crouch thy ‸Thy bearded throat and thy high–borne forehead to the
gutter
Crouch low thy neck to eleemosynary gifts.
